Hie diddle, diddle,
The Cat and the Fiddle,
The Cow jump'd over the Moon ;
The little Dog laugh'd to see such sport,
While the Dish ran awav with the Spoon.

The King was in the Counting House, counting out his Monty,
The Queen was in the Parlour, eating Bread and Honev ;

T h e whole produced u n d e r the Direction of Mr. FARLEY.

Little Jack Horner, sat in a corner,
Eating a Christmas pie;
He pat in his thumb,
And pull'd out a plumb,
Saving what a good boy am I.

fgjp In consequence of the Rrllllant Reception
OF T H C N E W GRAND FAIRY BALLET O F T H E .

And the enthusiastic Applause produced by the united Exertions of

Mademoiselle PAULINE LEROUX,
Mademoiselle CAVA,
Mademoiselle LARCHE.
Mademoiselle VAGON,
And Monsieur SILVAIN,

It will be repeated This Evening, Tuesday and Thursday, next, to
which nights in each week it is necessarily confined, notwithstanding
its unprecedented success, owing to the Season of Lent.

Owing to the C O M P L E T E

OVERFLOWS,

An extra Pit Door will be opened, and all Privileges will be entirely
suspended.

G0STAWS THE THIRD:

Was last Evening performed for the 76th Night, and while
Public Opinion has pronounced it to be one of the most
Splendid Dramas ever produced on the English Stage tha.t
Opinion has been confirmed by the largest Receipts ever
taken for such a continued Period. Its performance however can not be resumed before Monday next, in consequence
of the necessity for
RENOVATING T H E SCENERY, DRESSES & DECORATIONS,

For the 2nd Time in the course ofthe Season

in order that the numerous Families now coming to Town
may have an opportunity
of seeing it fW.

GUSTAVUS T H E

THIRD:

Was performed on Monday, for the 76th Night, and while
Public Opinion has pronounced it to be one of the most
Splendid Dramas ever produced on the English Stage that
Opinion has been confirmed by the largest Receipts ever
taken for such a continued Period. Its performance however can not be resumed before Monday next, in Consequence
of the necessity for
RENOVATING T H E SCENERY, BRASSES & DECORATIONS,

For the 2nd Time in the course of the Season

in order that the numerous Families now coming to Town
may have an opportunity of seeing it in its original splendour.

GUSTAVUS T H E T H I R D :

Was performed on Monday, for the 76th Night, and while
Public Opinion has pronounced it to be one of the most
Splendid Dramas ever produced on the English Stage that
Opinion has been confirmed by the largest Receipts ever
taken for such a continued Period. Its performance however can not be resumed before Monday next, in consequence
of the necessity for
RENOVATING T H E S C E N E R Y , D R £ S S £S & DECORATIONS,

for t h e 2nd Time in t h e course of t h e Season

*n order that the numerous Families now coming to Town
^ a y have an opportunity ofseeing it in its original splendour*

GRAND

BOOK*, with a Programme of the Story may be had in the Theatre, and of Mr. MILLER, Henrietta 'treet, f ovent (tardea.

After which, the

SCIENTIFIC

MARCH

PART I .

Feats of Science exhibited in '20 different Representations, with Musical

AJTD

HF,a(l'LEA\ FEAT
I. Ciame with three cannon balls, of 15, :10, and 40 Iks. each. ,
f. The balls are made to dance troin arm to arm on the sense muscles,
above the elbow, and so roll from the end ot one hand across the back
or breast to the end of the other, rolling over the head
3. The hurling of the balls. The heaviest ball is flung by the feet
backward* to a very great height, and is received and balanced in its
descent upon the back and arm.
H

ATHLETIC

S

O F STHEMGTH

4. force of the balls. The ball is flung backwards from between the
feet and alights upon the neck, over the head and f a c , down to the back
of the hand, where it is balanced.
5. Aeriel excursion upon the Dutch windmill. Mr. Rappo will
place himself upon the extreme end of one of the wings of the windmill
and thus have himself swung round and round with th« mill.

PART I I I _ _ ^ ^ _
FEATS OF STHEJk'CrTH

1. Mr. Rappo will give, with several hundred pounds weight of iron,
numerous proofs of his muscular strength.
2. He will place himself in various difficult positions, suspend himself
horizontally upon a chair, holding at the same time the heaviest pieces
of iron ; also with his feet bound, together, and grasping in each hand
a massive piece of iron, leap over several men.
I . He will walk round the stage bearing in his arms four strong'
built men.
4. Hercules plays with the heavy clu'o, which he turns and throws
around him in different forms, and attaching to it an additional weight
of a cannon ball of 40lbs., he places upon it a glass and balances the
whole together upon his forehead, teeth, aim, and hand, and concludes
by holding it upon his finger.

5. The athletic pantomimic representation, in ancient costume of
Hercules during his struggles. The attitudes are formed after the best
models in painting and sculpture. Those now exhibited represent the
hero in conflict with-the Nemean lion, the serpent of Lerna and the
I'.urvmanthean boan>T>y whom he is simultaniously attacked. Surrounded
by these monsters, he uses his club, according to a poetical precept,
sometimes in defence, sometimes in attack, and at last comes off with the
triumphant joy of the victor.
ti. the last exhibition will dtsolay the highest achievements of human
strength by the Hercules, inasmuch as he holds himself suspended in the
air hanging to a perpendicular iron pole, and thus swings his body round
the pole with the swiftness of lightning.

To conclude with the New Faree called

A GOOD LOOKJJG FELLOW.

in it To-morrow Evening, and on Monday next.

Then dreams he of another benefice,—
Sometimes she driveth o'er a Soldier's nerk "

The Drama by E. FITZBALL.—The Music by RODWELL ant BLEWITT—The Scenery by MARSHALL,—The Machinery by Mr. SLOMAN.
'Many of your Lordships muat recollect what used to take place on the Highroads, in the neighbourhood of this Metropolis
" tome years ago. Scarcely a carriage could pass without being robbed, and frequently the passengers w e r e obliged to fight
' with, and give battle to the Highwaymen, who infested the Roads :"

WELL,

" Many of your Lordships must recollect what used toitake place on the Highroads, in the neighbourhood of this Metropolis
' some years ago. Scarcely a carriage could pass -without being robbed, and frequently the passengers were obliged to fight
•' with, and give battle to the Highwaymen, who infested the Roads :"

' Many of your Lordships must recollect what used to-:take place on the Highroads, in the neighbourhood of this Metropolis
" some years ago. Scarcely a carriage could pass -without being robbed, and frequently the passengers were obliged to fight
;
' with, and give battle to the Highwaymen, -who infested the Roads : "

NOTICE.
